Welcome

Welcome to my website! My name is Greg Anderson, and I am a Geospatial and Statistical Analyst for a consulting firm and a part time doctoral student in the Department of Fish and Wildlife Conservation at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University.This website hosts my current research, ePortfolio, and blog on quantitative ecology. If you would like to get to know more about me, feel free to view my curriculum vitae or view the primer on Greg Anderson below.

About My Blog on Quantitative Ecology

The purpose of my blog is to focus on different quantitative topics that I have found intriguing and implement these topics in R, JAGS (Just Another Gibbs Sampler), or Python. Each post includes exercises and scripts that I have developed in one of these languages. I will cover a range of topics in this blog, including: geostatistics, MCMC, Moran’s Eigenvector Maps, mark-recapture models, and occupancy estimation models. The goal of most of these posts is to develop functions or models that are fully functional for multiple users and uses.  Therefore, each post’s content will also be available within one of my repositories on git hub. Below are a few of my most recent posts:

A Primer on Greg Anderson

Oddly, my interest in ecology originated when I was an undergraduate history major. Although these disciplines are seemingly unrelated, my understanding of the ways in which humans affect the natural landscape (and vice-versa) was shaped within a historical context.  After receiving my B.A. from the University of Georgia, I was eager to change directions, and I began working as a laboratory technician in the Odum School of Ecology and later received my M.S. in Ecology from the same institution.

Since then, my research has evolved to incorporate ecology and conservation within a framework that supports the needs of organisms in landscapes that are changing due to anthropogenic disturbances.The majority of my past research has been the application of quantitative conservation practices to further understand the need and requirements of organisms (mostly aquatic) and has involved linking changes in land-use, climate, or policy to changes in populations of organisms. My analysis techniques have often centered on understanding and quantifying uncertainty.

For the most part, I have focused my research on rare and elusive fishes, especially darters. Although this fauna is incredibly diverse and unique, it also demonstrates a high degree of imperilment, and there is a paucity of information on basic population attributes (e.g., occupancy and abundance patterns or survival rates from disturbances) for most species. The existence of this high diversity within an increasingly altered landscape has created complex conservations issues that cannot be solved using traditional methods of conservation biology, and that is where my research comes in.

Gregory B. Anderson

Dept. of Fish and Wildlife Conservation Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University Blacksburg, VA 24061
